Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Reducing Computation in Empirical Likelihood Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
The study of empirical likelihood methods has attracted much attention in many areas of statistics. This proposal develops new procedures to overcome the computational burden in applying these methods to inference problems in different settings such as: estimating equations, stationary sequences, high-dimensional data, Pickands dependence functions in multivariate extreme-value distributions and copulas in risk management. A practical obstacle in using empirical likelihood methods is the computational issue due to the high dimensional data, the large size of nuisance parameters as well as dependence in the data. The investigators intend to develop new methodologies to overcome the computational problems and extend the scope of the potential applications.

The new research results can be applied to economics, insurance, finance, risk management and other social sciences that require effective tools for exploring nonlinear dependence among multivariate series and to increase the complexity of the models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Method of maximum Likelihood is one of the most widely used statistical tools for statistical inference. As a non-parametric method, empirical likelihood method defines likelihood for data without assuming a parametric distribution and has been proved to be a very accurate in statistical inference including construction of confidence regions and tests of hypotheses.   The empirical likelihood approach has been applied to linear functionals very effectively but there is a computational burden when it is applied to nonlinear functional due to the high dimensionality or complexity of a statistical model. The project aims to develop new empirical likelihood methods and jackknife empirical likelihood method and some other likelihood methods and to extend the scope of likelihood method. The project has contributed in the following areas:  i) proposing jackknife empirical likelihood methods and reducing computation in estimating equations with nuisance parameters; ii) constructing intervals for copula and tail copula;  iii) testing high dimensional mean with the asymptotic limit independent of dimension; iv) obtaining the central limit theorems for likelihood ratio tests for high dimensional normal distributions; v) proposing new likelihood method for distributions with regularly varying tails.  The proposed new empirical likelihood method and jackknife empirical likelihood method are easy to implement, and comparison study demonstrates that they are powerful as well.   Our normal approximation to the likelihood ratio test outperforms the traditional chi-square approximation for high dimensional normal vectors.  The proposed new likelihood method extends the range of the tail index in extreme-value statistics to which the likelihood method can be used. The results from the project can be applied to model financial data and to analyze risks in insurance, finance and risk management,   for example, tail copulas are the standard tool in modeling dependence and tail dependence in risk management.  This project results in 14 journal publications and several technical reports in statistics. This project supports the principal investigator to present results in conferences and seminars.
